abstract.text: Interact with files, folders, and volumes.
Identifies a directory or file, including a volumeâ€™s root directory.
Create and resolve alias records that describe file system objects such as files, directories, and volumes.
Find and use components in your app or add custom components to system-provided services, such as QuickTime and Core Audio.
Interact with files, folders, and volumes.
Investigate the operating environment of your app.
Handle text encoding conversion between apps and transfer text across different platforms.

inlineContent.text: File Manager is deprecated in macOS 10.8 and later. The Foundation and Core Foundation frameworks provide APIs that you can use to replace File Manager functions in your app. See
To get notifications when a folder changes, use the File System Events API. See
To mount a local volume, use the Disk Arbitration API. You can unmount or eject a local volume by calling the
For low-level access, use POSIX and BSD APIs.

inlineContent.text: Using File Manager APIs on volumes formatted with APFS is strongly discouraged.
, aren't supported in APFS. Other functions may have different in behaviors APFS and HFS+, such as the returned order of directory entries by
, or how  file modification times are calculated by
. Several File Manager APIs interact with the
structure (also deprecated), which uses 32-bit inode numbers. This interaction can cause performance issues in APFS, which uses 64-bit inode numbers.
